name: CDA R2 Profile
description: Standard Profile for CDA R2 on FHIR

definition.short: A set of resources composed into a single coherent clinical statement with clinical attestation
definition.formal: A set of healthcare-related information that is assembled together into a single logical document that provides a single coherent statement of meaning, establishes its own context and that has clinical attestation with regard to who is making the statement.
definition.comments: While the focus of this specification is on patient-specific clinical statements, this resource can also apply to other healthcare-related statements such as study protocol designs, healthcare invoices and other activities that are not necessarily patient-specific or clinical.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
definition.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

definition.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
definition.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.formal: Logical Identifier for the composition, assigned when created. This identifier stays constant as the composition is changed over time.
definition.comments: See discussion in resource definition for how these relate.

definition.formal: The composition editing time, when the composition was last logically changed by the author.
definition.comments: The Last Modified Date on the composition may be after the date of the document was attested without being changed.

definition.formal: Specifies the particular kind of composition (e.g. History and Physical, Discharge Summary, Progress Note). This usually equates to the purpose of making the composition.

binding.name: DocumentType
binding.description: Type of a composition

definition.formal: A categorization for the type of the composition. This may be implied by or derived from the code specified in the Composition Type.

binding.name: DocumentClass
binding.description: SubType of a clinical document

definition.formal: Official human-readable label for the composition.
definition.comments: If compositions do not have a title, the text or a display name of Composition.type (e.g. a "consultation" or "progress note") can be used in it's place.

definition.formal: CDA: all documents are final
definition.comments: If a composition is marked as withdrawn, the compositions/documents in the series, or data from the composition or document series, should never be displayed to a user without being clearly marked as untrustworthy. The flag "withdrawn" is why this element is labeled as a modifier of other elements.

binding.name: CompositionStatus
binding.description: The workflow/clinical status of the composition

definition.formal: The code specifying the level of confidentiality of the Composition.
definition.comments: The exact use of this element, and enforcement and issues related to highly sensitive documents are out of scope for FHIR, and delegated to implementation profiles (see security section).

binding.name: DocumentConfidentiality
binding.description: Codes specifying the level of confidentiality of the composition

definition.formal: Who or what the composition is about. The composition can be about a person, (patient or healthcare practitioner), a device (I.e. machine) or even a group of subjects (such as a document about a herd of livestock, or a set of patients that share a common exposure).
definition.comments: For clinical documents, this is usually the patient.

definition.short: Who and/or what authored the composition
definition.formal: Identifies who is responsible for the information in the composition.  (Not necessarily who typed it in.).
A participant who has attested to the accuracy of the composition/document.
definition.comments: Only list each attester once.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: The type of attestation the authenticator offers.
definition.comments: Use more than one code where a single attester has more than one mode (professional and legal are often paired).

binding.name: CompositionAttestationMode
binding.description: The way in which a person authenticated a composition

definition.formal: When composition was attested by the party.
Who attested the composition in the specified way.

mapping.map:
./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and isNormalEntity()]
or
./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole and not(player)]/scoper[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="ORG" and isNormalEntity()]

./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "PSN") and isNormalEntity()] or ./role[classCode="ASSIGNED" and isNormalRole and not(player)]/scoper[determinerCode="INST" and classCode="ORG" and isNormalEntity()]

definition.formal: Identifies the organization or group who is responsible for ongoing maintenance of and access to the composition/document information.
definition.comments: This is useful when documents are derived from a composition - provides guidance for how to get the latest version of the document. This is optional because knowing this is sometimes not known by the authoring system, and can be inferred by context. However it's important that this information be known when working with a derived document, so providing a custodian is encouraged.

definition.formal: The main event/act/item, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented.
definition.comments: The event needs to be consistent with the type element, though can provide further information if desired.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
definition.comments: there can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core simplicity for everyone.

definition.short: Code(s) that apply to the event being documented
definition.formal: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts, such as a colonoscopy or an appendectomy, being documented. In some cases, the event is inherent in the typeCode, such as a "History and Physical Report" in which the procedure being documented is necessarily a "History and Physical" act.
definition.comments: An event can further specialize the act inherent in the typeCode, such as where it is simply "Procedure Report" and the procedure was a "colonoscopy". If one or more eventCodes are included, they SHALL NOT conflict with the values inherent in the classCode, practiceSettingCode or typeCode, as such a conflict would create an ambiguous situation. This short list of codes is provided to be used as “key words” for certain types of queries.

binding.name: DocumentEventType
binding.description: This list of codes represents the main clinical acts being documented

definition.short: The period covered by the documentation
definition.formal: The period of time covered by the documentation. There is no assertion that the documentation is a complete representation for this period, only that it documents events during this time.

definition.short: Full details for the event(s) the composition consents
definition.formal: Full details for the event(s) the composition/documentation consents.
Describes the clinical encounter or type of care this documentation is associated with.

mapping.map: unique(highest(./outboundRelationship[typeCode="SUBJ" and isNormalActRelationship()], priorityNumber)/target[moodCode="EVN" and classCode=("ENC", "PCPR") and isNormalAct])

definition.formal: The root of the sections that make up the composition.

constraint.name: Section Rule
constraint.human: A section SHALL have content or one or more sections, but not both.

definition.formal: The heading for this particular section.  This will be part of the rendered content for the document.
A code identifying the kind of content contained within the section.

binding.name: CompositionSectionType
binding.description: Classification of a composition / document

definition.formal: Identifies the primary subject of the section.
definition.comments: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications SHALL be aware if the subject changes for a particular section.

mapping.map:
unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="PAT"])
or
unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="IDENT"]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "ORG") and isNormalEntity()])

unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="PAT"]) or unique(./participation[typeCode="SBJ" and isNormalParticipation]/role[typeCode="IDENT"]/player[determinerCode="INST" and classCode=("DEV", "ORG") and isNormalEntity()])

definition.short: The actual data for the section
definition.formal: Identifies the discrete data that provides the content for the section.
definition.comments: Because composition represent point-in-time snapshots, resource references should either be to a specific version, or made against resources on the same server with full version tracking, so that the correct versions can easily be assembled.

definition.formal: Demographics and other administrative information about a person or animal receiving care or other health-related services.

definition.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.formal: An identifier that applies to this person as a patient.
A name associated with the individual.
definition.comments: Person may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods.For animals, the name is a "HumanName" in the sense that is assigned and used by humans and has the same patterns.

definition.formal: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the individual may be contacted.
definition.comments: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently and also to help with identification. The address may not go directly to the individual, but may reach another party that is able to proxy for the patient (i.e. home phone, or pet owner's phone).

definition.formal: Administrative Gender - the gender that the patient is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
definition.comments: The gender may not match the biological sex as determined by genetics, or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than M and F, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support M and F.

binding.name: AdministrativeGender
binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes

definition.formal: The date and time of birth for the individual.
definition.comments: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real dob is unknown.

definition.short: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not
definition.formal: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
definition.comments: If there's no value in the instance it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.

mapping.map: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd,player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

definition.formal: Addresses for the individual.
definition.comments: Person may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods.

definition.formal: This field contains a patient's most recent marital (civil) status.

binding.name: MaritalStatus
binding.description: The domestic partnership status of a person

definition.short: Whether patient is part of a multiple birth
definition.formal: Indicates whether the patient is part of a multiple or indicates the actual birth order.
Image of the person.
A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient.
definition.comments: Contact covers all kinds of contact parties: family members, business contacts, guardians, caregivers. Not applicable to register pedigree and family ties beyond use of having contact.

constraint.name: ContactNeedsDetails
constraint.human: SHALL at least contain a contact's details or a reference to an organization
constraint.xpath: f:name or f:telecom or f:address or f:organization

definition.formal: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person.

binding.name: ContactRelationship
binding.description: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient

definition.short: in CDA, only Guardian is allowed
definition.formal: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person.

binding.name: ContactRelationship
binding.description: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient

definition.formal: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person.

binding.name: ContactRelationship
binding.description: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient

definition.formal: A name associated with the person.

definition.short: A contact detail for the guardian
definition.formal: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
definition.comments: Person may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods. May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.

definition.formal: Address for the contact person.
Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.

binding.name: AdministrativeGender
binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes

definition.short: Organization that acts as guardian for the contact
definition.formal: Organization on behalf of which the contact is acting or for which the contact is working.

definition.short: If this patient is an animal (non-human)
definition.formal: This element has a value if the patient is an animal.
definition.comments: The animal element is labeled "Is Modifier" since patients may be non-human. Systems SHALL either handle patient details appropriately (e.g. inform users patient is not human) or reject non-human patient records.

definition.formal: Identifies the high level categorization of the kind of animal.
definition.comments: If the patient is non-human, at least a species SHALL be specified.

binding.name: AnimalSpecies
binding.description: The species of an animal

definition.formal: Identifies the detailed categorization of the kind of animal.

binding.name: AnimalBreed
binding.description: The breed of an animal

definition.formal: Indicates the current state of the animal's reproductive organs.

binding.name: AnimalGenderStatus
binding.description: The state of the animal's reproductive organs

definition.formal: Languages which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health.
definition.comments: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken.For animals, language is not a relevant field, and should be absent from the instance.

binding.name: Language
binding.description: A human language

definition.short: Code defined by a terminology system
definition.formal: A reference to a code defined by a terminology system.
definition.comments: Codes may be defined very casually in enumerations, or code lists, up to very formal definitions such as SNOMED CT - see the V3 Core Principles for more information.  Ordering of codings is undefined and SHALL not be used to infer meaning.

definition.short: Plain text representation of the concept
definition.formal: A human language representation of the concept as seen/selected/uttered by the user who entered the data and/or which represents the intended meaning of the user.
definition.comments: Very often the text is the same as a displayName of one of the codings.

mapping.map: C*E.9. But note many systems use C*E.2 for this

definition.formal: Patient's nominated care provider.

definition.short: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record
definition.formal: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record.

definition.short: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person
definition.formal: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person.
definition.comments: There is no assumption that linked patient records have mutual links.

definition.formal: The other patient resource that the link refers to.

definition.short: replace | refer | seealso - type of link
definition.formal: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

binding.name: LinkType
binding.description: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

definition.short: Whether this patient's record is in active use
definition.formal: Whether this patient record is in active use.
definition.comments: Default is true. If a record is inactive, and linked to an active record, then future patient/person/record updates should occur on the other patient.

definition.short: in CDA, only Guardian is allowed
A contact detail for the guardian

definition.formal: Address for the contact person.

definition.short: Organization that acts as guardian for the contact
Organization that is the custodian of the patient record

definition.formal: A formally or informally recognized grouping of people or organizations formed for the purpose of achieving some form of collective action.  Includes companies, institutions, corporations, departments, community groups, healthcare practice groups, etc.

constraint.name: AtLeastANameOrId
constraint.human: The organization SHALL at least have a name or an id, and possibly more than one

definition.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
definition.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

definition.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
definition.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.formal: Identifier for the organization that is used to identify the organization across multiple disparate systems.

mapping.map: XON.10 Organization Identifier / XON.3 ID Number

definition.formal: A name associated with the organization.
The kind of organization that this is.
definition.comments: Organizations can be corporations, wards, sections, clinical teams, government departments, etc. Note that code is generally a classifier of the type of organization; in many applications, codes are used to identity a particular organization (say, ward) as opposed to another of the same type - these are identifiers, not codes.

definition.formal: A contact detail for the organization.
definition.comments: The use code home is not to be used. Note that these contacts are not the contact details of people who are employed by or represent the organization, but official contacts for the organization itself.

constraint.name: NoHomeUseTelecom
constraint.human: The telecom of an organization can never be of use 'home'

definition.formal: An address for the organization.
definition.comments: Organization may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods. The use code home is not to be used.

constraint.name: NoHomeUseAddress
constraint.human: An address of an organization can never be of use 'home'

mapping.map: No authoritative equivalent in V2.x; some V2.x segments such as OBX might provide a serialized instance value

definition.short: The organization of which this organization forms a part
definition.formal: The organization of which this organization forms a part.

definition.short: Relative, internal or absolute URL reference
definition.formal: A reference to a location at which the other resource is found. The reference may a relative reference, in which case it is relative to the service base URL, or an absolute URL that resolves to the location where the resource is found. The reference may be version specific or not. If the reference is not to a FHIR RESTful server, then it should be assumed to be version specific. Internal fragment references (start with '#') refer to contained resources.
definition.comments:
Using absolute URLs provides a stable scalable approach suitable for a cloud/web context, while using relative/logical references provides a flexible approach suitable for use when trading across closed eco-system boundaries. 

Absolute URLs do not need to point to a FHIR RESTful server, though this is the preferred approach. If the url conforms to the structure "/[type]/@[id]" then it should be assumed that the reference is to a FHIR RESTful server.

definition.formal: Plain text narrative that identifies the resource in addition to the resource reference.
definition.comments: This is generally not the same as the Resource.text of the referenced resource.  The purpose is to identify what's being referenced, not to fully describe it.

definition.short: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose
definition.formal: Contact for the organization for a certain purpose.

definition.short: A name associated with the contact
definition.formal: A name associated with the contact.

definition.short: Contact details (telephone, email, etc)  for a contact
definition.formal: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the party may be contacted.

definition.short: Visiting or postal addresses for the contact

Administrative Gender - the gender that the person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.

definition.formal: Location(s) the organization uses to provide services.

definition.short: Whether the organization's record is still in active use
definition.formal: Whether the organization's record is still in active use.
definition.comments: Default is true.

definition.formal: The organization of which this organization forms a part.

definition.formal: Name of the location as used by humans. Does not need to be unique.

definition.short: Description of the Location, which helps in finding or referencing the place

definition.formal: The contact details of communication devices available at the location. This can include phone numbers, fax numbers, mobile numbers, email addresses and web sites.
Physical location.
definition.comments: This was kept as 0..1 as there is no use property on the address, so wouldn't be able to identify different address types.

active | suspended | inactive.

structure.name: inFulFillmentOfDiagnosticOrder
structure.purpose: DiagnosticOrder resource as referred to in CDA

definition.formal: A request for a diagnostic investigation service to be performed.

definition.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. definition.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
definition.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

definition.formal: Who or what the investigation is to be performed on. This is usually a human patient, but diagnostic tests can also be requested on animals, groups of humans or animals, devices such as dialysis machines, or even locations (typically for environmental scans).
The practitioner that holds legal responsibility for ordering the investigation.
Identifiers assigned to this order by the order or by the receiver.

definition.short: The encounter that this diagnostic order is associated with
definition.formal: An encounter that provides additional information about the healthcare context in which this request is made.
An explanation or justification for why this diagnostic investigation is being requested.
definition.comments: This may be used to decide how the diagnostic investigation will be performed, or even if it will be performed at all.

definition.short: Supporting observations or conditions for this request
definition.formal: Additional clinical information about the patient or specimen that may influence test interpretations.
definition.comments: This information includes diagnosis, clinical findings and other observations.  Examples include reporting the amount of inspired carbon dioxide for blood gasses, the point in the menstrual cycle for cervical pap tests, and other conditions that influence test interpretations.

definition.short: If the whole order relates to specific specimens
definition.formal: One or more specimens that the diagnostic investigation is about.
definition.comments: Many investigation requests will create a need for specimens, but the request itself is not actually about the specimens. This is provided for when the diagnostic investigation is requested on already existing specimens.

definition.short: requested | received | accepted | in progress | review | completed | suspended | rejected | failed
definition.formal: The status of the order.
definition.comments: Typically the system placing the order sets the status to requested. There after, the order is maintained by the receiver that updates the status as the request is handled.

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderStatus
binding.description: The status of a diagnostic order

mapping.map:
.statusCode
also influenced by whether a ControlAct fulfillment requeste exists, whether a promise exists, status of the review component, whether a fulfilling observation exists, whether a refusal exists

definition.formal: The clinical priority associated with this order.
definition.comments: The Order resource also has a priority. Generally, these should be the same, but they can be different, for instance in the case where the clinician indicates that the order is urgent, but the subsequent workflow process overrule this priority for some reason. The effective default value is "normal".

binding.name: DiagnosticOrderPriority
binding.description: The clinical priority of a diagnostic order

definition.short: A list of events of interest in the lifecycle
definition.formal: A summary of the events of interest that have occurred as the request is processed. E.g. when the order was made, various processing steps (specimens received), when it was completed.
definition.comments: This is not the same as an audit trail - it is a view of the important things that happened in the past. Typically, there would only be one entry for any given status, and systems may not record all the status events.

The person who was responsible for performing or recording the action.

The specific diagnostic investigations that are requested as part of this request. Sometimes, there can only be one item per request, but in most contexts, more than one investigation can be requested.
definition.comments: There would always be at least one item in normal usage, but this is optional so that a workflow can quote order details without having to list the items.

definition.formal: A code that identifies a particular diagnostic investigation, or panel of investigations, that have been requested.
definition.comments: Many laboratory tests and radiology tests embed the specimen/organ system in the test name, for example,  serum or serum/plasma glucose, or a chest xray. The specimen may not be recorded separately from the test code.

binding.name: DiagnosticRequests
binding.description: Codes for tests/services that can be performed by diagnostic services

definition.short: If this item relates to specific specimens
definition.formal: If the item is related to a specific speciment.
definition.comments: A single specimen should not appear in both DIagnosticOrder.specimen and DiagnosticOrder.item.specimen.

definition.formal: Anatomical location where the request test should be performed.

binding.description: Codes describing anatomical locations. May include laterality
